bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, July 15, 1720

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant William Dawkins, July 15, 1720, concerning Dawkins' business affairs with Richard Lee, noting that Lee's father "was my Intimate friend" who had charged Carter with looking after his children which "makes me the unfittest person in the world to go into harsh measures agst. him." He assures Dawkins that Lee is honest but "too unsteady & too careless & easie" to do business for others. Lee will pledge his estate against the debts if Dawkins insists, but Carter points out that, after deductions for items due Lee, there will not be much balance due Dawkins. Carter notes that he will do whatever Dawkins wishes, but hopes that harsh measures will not be necessary.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, July 15, 1720

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
July 15th. 1720
Mr. Wm. Dawkins

div1.p:
In Yor. Affair wth. Mr. Richd. Lee I have taken
as much pain As If the Concern were my own herein You
have the Draft of an Accot. of his own Stateing for the
Several Cargos of Goods he hath had from You, whereby
It appears, The ball[an] ce between You is not much I dare
Say in his prices of the Tobos. he hath wronged himself &
not You, Since he hath bin concern'd for You [it] hath bin
The most Difficult time to Deal wth. our Plan[te]rs that ever
I knew, The outstanding Debts are indeed very large
& will be much to Yor. loss If Tobo. falls but this is very often
The Consequence when we trust for next years pay and there
is too many among us when a good Markett offers for their Tobo
will lay It out in Stores & leave their old Debts unpaid
wch. In a Great measure I take to be Yor. case I
Shall not take upon me to Justifye Mr. Lee's Conduct he
is too unsteady & too careless & easie, to do business for other men
but for his honesty I think If I know him I dare Answer
he offers You any Security You can desire by making
over his Estate, If You insist upon It, but when his Salary
That is behind is taken out and Storage pd. Yor. claim
upon him will be so small There will be hardly any
occasion for It, upon the whole I really believe
he'l be a Considerable looser by Yor. business wch.
is a hard case & Deserves Yor. Consideration I shall
be ready to Do You any Service wth. him You Shall Desire
believing You'l not be unreasonable in Yor. Demands
but You must remember his father was my Intimate
friend he left the care of his Children to me and the
Son hath bin my familiar acquaintenance since he
came to be a man— wch. makes me the unfittest
person in the world to go into harsh measures agst.
him, but I hope his promises are so fair to give You
all the sattisfaction in his power. no Grounds will
remain for such an unkind Step of wch. I should be
very glad to hear
div1.closer:
who am Sir
Yor. very hum Srt

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 28-29.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.
